00081 /*
00082 It turns out that many libraries and tools make use of
00083 symbols like "debug" and "fatal".  This causes strange
00084 failures when we link against such codes.  Rather than change
00085 all of our code, we simply insert these defines to
00086 transparently modify the linker namespace we are using.
00087 */
00088 
00089 #define debug                  cctools_debug
00090 #define fatal                  cctools_fatal
00091 #define debug_config           cctools_debug_config
00092 #define debug_config_file      cctools_debug_config_file
00093 #define debug_config_file_size cctools_debug_config_file_size
00094 #define debug_config_fatal     cctools_debug_config_fatal
00095 #define debug_config_getpid    cctools_debug_config_getpid
00096 #define debug_flags_set        cctools_debug_flags_set
00097 #define debug_flags_print      cctools_debug_flags_print
00098 #define debug_flags_clear      cctools_debug_flags_clear
00099 #define debug_flags_restore    cctools_debug_flags_restore
00100 
00107 void debug( INT64_T flags, const char *fmt, ... );
00108 
00114 void fatal( const char *fmt, ... );
00115 
00121 void debug_config( const char *name );
00122 
00129 void debug_config_file( const char *file );
00130 
00138 void debug_config_file_size( int size );
00139 
00140 void debug_config_fatal( void (*callback) () );
00141 void debug_config_getpid( pid_t (*getpidfunc)() );
00142 
00151 int  debug_flags_set( const char *flagname );
00152 
00159 void debug_flags_print( FILE *stream );
00160 
00166 int  debug_flags_clear();
00167 
00168 #endif
